author: djmermoz
title: NFBooks: a Pan-African NFT library
description: In Africa, access to books and ebooks is severely limited. Numerous factors are at play against mass adoption of a reading culture which negatively affect all involved parties (authors, readers, etc).

f6_assessments.q0:
-	Awesome proposal submission the content management space focussing on books, african culture and focussing on Cameroun as a starting point. 
-	The submission challenges business models in the publishing  industry for  rights licensing , monetization, co-authoring, publishing reputation, readership engagement as we know them
-	This proposal brings together Digital Rights Management, social networking and marketplace features all in one platform aiming to decentralize and disrupt the publishing industy by bringing authors,  artists, content creators , advertisers, publishers and reader community together 
-	In doing so, it challenges the Cardano Ecosystem to provide tools needed for such innovations to materialize and also positions Cardano to compete with some recent products like Creatokia (https://www.creatokia.com/en)  , Openaccess publishers, Ebook platforms and e-readers.
-	The team is qualified, experienced in IT and is expanding its networking with authors/publishers. The big challenge is more about implementing features they’ve identified, scaling up rapidly as a social marketplace. Some interesing features have been documented by bookriot (https://bookriot.com/nfts-for-books/ )
-	This could definitely scale to the broader African continent and worldwide.
f6_assessments.q1:
-	The cost breakdown appears to be adequate and brings together competencies much needed at this early startup stage (research, engineering, management)
-	The roadmap and immediate objectives with timeframes for this proposal could benefit from some further clarification as the team is starting from scratch.
-	Scoping out a Proof of Concept, then a Minimum Viable Product based on customer needs research, could be helpful before investing directly into a final product concept. The team could further test the audience engagement, interaction with mockups to how best adoption could work given the challenges highlighted in the proposal with regards to a missing reading culture.
-	Some further details on the go to market strategy could help better understand if there may be some gaps in this respect, i.e marketing and communications campaign and gearing up with an operations team, business developers & partnership managers  to develop the partnerships needed. 
-	Setting up a business model canvas to explore an operating business model could highlight some other gaps or hypotheses that the team is making and allow the team to test them ( https://www.strategyzer.com/canvas/business-model-canvas) 
-	The tokenomics for a blockchain based application would also need to be designed to clarify the incentivization model, licensing and royalty payments through utility or payment tokens or fiat money. Each payment interface implementation can have a cost, and maybe integrating payment channels ( fiat, MPesa etc) with high adoption rates can help drive adoption for starting off.
-	Books can eventually evolve as a multi-NFT universe on their own, and innovative business models like co-authoring, co-reviewing, using art NFT, media NFTs can unleash new business opportunities and value chains. The team may find it useful to research the market dynamics possible with these other NFT communities ( art, media) to design the final product.

f6_assessments.q2:
-	The team is clear on customer acquisition (reader, author, publisher), retention and product adoption being the key outcomes they are after through the launch of their app. As there is a go to market phase, the team may find it useful to include some indicators for feedback collection eg : number of users using it, number of interviews, ( groups, individuals) , feature requests using a user-voice & voting mechanism. It will be useful to gauge how well the product is being received by customers and the potential for growing it into a mature product.
-	As this is a space where users will spend quite some time engaging with book and the app, the product needs to be solid in terms of customer experience and stable in order to develop the customer acquisition level it clearly deserves. Poor user experience could probably adversely affect growth, so some caution may be needed there. It may be useful to measure forms of customer engagement like time spent on app, books read, annotations, reviews, comments etc.
-	Nonetheless, some operational KPIs may be handy as the user-base scales, eg, some performance related metrics like number of crashes of application, outages, support requests and resolution rates. This could inform the sizing of the operations team needed as the application scales. The team has planned for this and it will surely help them to plan their business model to meet customer satisfaction.

f6_assessments.q1:
This is a very passionate part presented of the project. All plans last 38 months, divided into 5 specific phases. I have a suggestion, instead of spreading and stretching, the project should be divided into 2 or 3 small proposals, preferably 3 proposals. For example, completing the research and securing the partnership is proposal 1, architectural design and technical documentation is recommendation 2, and implementing the foundation is recommendation 3. That helps the project to put its full potential team's strength in each stage. The construction of a specific roadmap for each stage will be more detailed, helping the project to be closer to the issues. The community is easy to monitor and evaluate. At the same time, in the process of implementing each proposal, the project has time to align its plan with the actual development.
With a total application budget of 52,000 USD for 6 members who worked hard for 38 months, this is a reasonable number, accounting for only 0.7% of the total budget of the Challenge. Recommended practices are presented in detail, I completely agree with this part
These are my small suggestions, with all that the project presents, I rate 5 points

Given their explanation on why this should be tackled, I completely agree with this statement. The team behind this proposal aims at creating an NFT book library focused on promoting a reading culture in Africa starting in CMR which will not only greatly expand and facilitate access to books but also provide incentives to readers. Despite being a huge project, the team cleverly divided it into four major phases, allowing the community to assess the impact the team aims to make in each phase. There is a description with a high level of detail of core elements/components the team plans to implement. The main deliverables are described clearly as an NFBook marketplace fit for the African context. For this, the potential for adoption is real, which is in line with the objectives of the challenge. I adore the idea, the pertinent solution, and the technical understanding included into the executed plan. The proposer also goes out of his way to explain how the project would benefit each group of stakeholders. There is nothing else to say; the team did an excellent job presenting this proposal. I have no trouble finding a direct relationship between the metrics provided and the intended outcome of this challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: There is already a dedicated team with experience in the proposed activities. The provided sources can also be used to verify the information. Based on the information presented, I feel the proposers have the necessary expertise and skills to carry out this project effectively. Based on the evidence, the proposal timeline and milestones are clearly specified, and the suggested time frame is appropriate for the amount of events outlined to be completed. I believe the amount of funding requested is appropriate for the benefit this project will bring to the community. However, I would have preferred to see more specifics in the budget. How many developers will be involved in the implementation, and will they all be paid the same hourly rate? Finally, the team presents a whole section outlining the risks that were identified at the time, as well as the solutions that were taken to lessen or eliminate them. This plan will be done successfully, in my opinion.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal targets at motivating book reading in Africa - a place where the book community is met with several obstacles. The solution will be an NFT book library that promotes reading culture in Africa. The proposer is able to give an analysis about the reading culture in Africa - the target market where good-quality historical and cultural books haven’t earned a widespread readership. The proposer also analyses the obstacles for book reading in Africa (high cost of printing, lack of digital library, undeveloped reading culture, no incentives). Seeing these problems, the proposer intends to create a NFT book (trackable on blockchain) with audio version. The proposal may elaborate the impact of the NFT book library on the blockchain community. Advertisement and sponsorship is also offered on this platform as a way to lower cost. Suggestion for incentives is illustrated by Mermoz’s trial - where he offers monetary prizes for students who read and take notes as guided. There are several recreational activities to promote reading culture on this platform. The platform also integrates a search engagement that caters for African cultural context (understanding symbolic African paradigm). This helps searching for African books easier and gives exposure to books whose names are written in paradigm. The proposer also considers the DID module for decentralized identity. This proposal is very well-presented in that it is made to solve a problem while integrating the blockchain technology. It also resolves authorship as the authors will earn not only publicity but also sales from the secondary market while maintaining their copyrights and ownership. Translators and publishers also get to see some benefits offered to them, validating this project as a win-win situation that aims to promote reading culture in Africa rather than profiting off others’ works. The main risk is lack of reception due to an unestablished reading culture. This is also the reason why this project is created and the mitigation is able to tackle both ends (the provider - authors, publishers and receiver - readers). The proposer can have a brief analysis about this project’s impact on the Cardano/Catalyst community (publicity, expansion of ecosystem, more recognition in a potential market - Africa). The proposer could also put more emphasis on the impact of this project on African reading culture and literature future - more profound books are created by African authors, people in Africa read more historical books and become more invested in their culture.
f6_assessments.q1: The plan is extremely detailed, with consideration for the local context of Cameroon. Activities in each phase are explained with great details. The proposer slowly connects the project together, starting from dealing with authors (give them reliable contracts, support for research,..), partnership with reputable names, design with guidance about specific modules (inventory, search, catalog, pricing, translation,....). Nearing the last steps, the proposer specifies the main deliverables (for specification documents) and finally implements the platform. Similarly, the budget breakdown is also presented in a detailed way. However, it will be even more detailed if the proposer could specify the salary paid to each of the positions listed (how much for expert fees, designers per hour, what’s in marketing - advertisement posts, billboards). It is understandable that a total amount of these fees have been provided. The further breakdown is for more transparency. The introduction of team members is also clear with specific specialty and role in the project (who does what). The working experiences are relevant and essential for the project (software developers, writer, researcher,...). Further funding in later rounds may not be needed.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has clear consideration to provide quantifiable deliverables, which helps auditing easier. Similarly, the proposer also views their success in various aspects: more readership, more profit, lower cost, formal research done by search engine. Suc consideration shows the project to be well-rounded and meticulous which gives way for validity, transparency and positive impact. SDG goals could be provided to highlight these positive impacts because it has such a big potential for making great contributions to the community.
